content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

This is not fun for reverse.
The additional rule that "because you sing so loud, the next heard line is never the line that your program just wrote!" is not something that you can just guess easily in reverse mode.

Whoever Brian Doerksen is,
there's no test case like his, only a validator,
which i think should be rectified.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really greate, even tho it's quite simple it's a kind of thing rare in current coc we get, good job

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I played it reverse first, and it was a fun experience with smartly ordered cases (had to correct my code a couple of times along the test cases).

After that I was pleasantly surprised about how much the statement also makes sense for this puzzle. A smart and creative implementation of concert experience into a coding challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'accepte cette proposition parce que, j'ai apprécié le fait de la référence à la musique dans un algorithme. C'est trop amusant

Interesting idea!

Input section
* You may write "Next line" instead of "Line N+1" for clarity.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer" or "write lyrics").

Goal section / Constraints section
* Please explain what the output should be if there are same lines of lyrics with different next lines of lyrics. Take the first test case as an example, what should be the output if the heard line is "Schwimmen auf dem See"? Should the output be "Schwimmen auf dem See" or "Köpfchen in das Wasser"?

Actually, this is an issue in "Brian Doerksen" Validator and "Marseillaise" test, for example.

Alternatively, please add a constraint that such lyrics will never appear in the heard lines.

Constraints section
* Please mention that the heard line is never the last line of the song lyrics.

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback! I've updated:
* input section
* stub generator
* goal section
* constraint section

I agree that the Brian Doerksen Validator could have been problematic, so I changed it slightly and clarified in the description that the line that was just written can never be the next heard line.
Thanks for the kind feedback. Is there actually a way to test a community clash in Reverse? I.e. seeing only test cases, not validators?

It took my a bit to understand what your referring to. I guess you're referring to the concept that the "next heard line is never the line that your program just wrote" in connection with Reverse mode. I'm changing the Marseillaise test case now.
completely agree - but Reverse mode should be disabled, or not?

It was enabled before, but now it's disabled which is for the best.
I played it in reverse and it was too hard.

I do not know of a proper way of testing in reverse (actually, it would be good if Codingame added the functionality that 'Test in IDE' has a twofold option 'test as Reverse' or 'test with goal statement'); but 'Test in IDE automatically opens a new tab, so I 'test in reverse' by checking the cases on the contribution tab, and solving it in the IDE tab. Not a fully good test in reverse, because indeed then I also see the validators.
